Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的演说往往都很冗长乏味。

Sense.DEF: if a way of doing something is long-winded, it is very complicated
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole process is incredibly long-winded.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 整个过程繁琐得叫人难以相信。

Sense.DEF: a toilet
Sense.EXAMPLE: I need to go to the loo use the toilet .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我要去一下洗手间。

Sense.DEF:
a rough bath
sponge
made from the dried inner part of a tropical fruit

PIC.HEADING: LOOK 看
PIC.PICCONTENT: Jane was blindfolded so she couldn't see anything. 简蒙着眼睛，什么也看不见。；He was looking at the painting. 他在看画。；Mark was watching TV. 马克在看电视。

Sense.DEF: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
Sense.EXAMPLE: We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们趁杰茜的妈妈没有看到﹐偷偷地溜了出去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果仔细看﹐就会看出画上是一个人形。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉娜捂住眼睛﹐不敢看。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘It’s time we left,’ Ian said, looking at his watch.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: “我们该走了。” 伊恩看了看表说。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她走进房间的时候﹐所有男人都转过来看她。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 爸爸从报纸上抬起头来看了看后笑了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘We can’t go out in this weather,’ said Bob, looking out of the window.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: “这样的天气我们不能出去。” 鲍勃看着窗外说。

Sense.DEF: to try to find something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I looked everywhere but Jimmy was nowhere to be found.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我到处都找遍了﹐可吉米还是不见踪影。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Could you help me look for my contact lens?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你帮我找一下隐形眼镜好吗？
GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you’re looking for a bargain, try the local market.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你想找便宜货﹐到当地的市场去看看吧。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Try looking under the bed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 在床底下找找看。

Sense.DEF: to seem
Sense.EXAMPLE: From the way things look at the moment, the Republicans are unlikely to win this election.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 照目前的形势来看﹐本届大选共和党获胜无望。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The future’s looking good.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 前途看似一片光明。

GramExa.GLOSS: it seems likely that
GramExa.EXAMPLE: It looks as if it might rain later.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 看来一会儿可能要下雨。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: It looks like they won’t be needing us any more.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 看来他们不再需要我们了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: You made me look really stupid in front of all my friends!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你让我在所有朋友面前出尽了洋相！

Sense.DEF: to have a particular appearance
Sense.EXAMPLE: How do I look?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我看上去怎么样？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You look tired. You should go to bed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你看上去很累﹐应该上床睡觉了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He looked as if he hadn’t washed for a week.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他看上去好像一个星期没有洗澡了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: What did the man look like ?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那人长相如何？
Sense.EXAMPLE: My sister doesn’t look anything like me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我妹妹长得一点也不像我。

Sense.DEF: to look at someone with a very angry expression on your face
to look at someone carefully from their head to their feet, as if you were forming an opinion about them
to look directly at someone when you are speaking to them, especially to show that you are not afraid of them or that you are telling the truth
Sense.TRAN: 正视某人〔尤表示不怕对方或自己说的是实话〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Owen didn’t dare look his father in the eye.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 欧文不敢正眼看父亲。

Sense.LEXUNIT: look down your nose at sb/sth
Sense.DEF: to behave as if you think that someone or something is not good enough for you
Sense.TRAN: 看不起某人/某事物﹐轻视某人/某事物
Sense.EXAMPLE: He looks down his nose at anyone foreign.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他看不起外国人。

Sense.DEF: to ignore something bad that is happening and not try to stop it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Prison guards looked the other way as the man was attacked by fellow prisoners.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那人遭其狱友殴打时﹐狱警掉过头去装作没看见。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something you are offering is exactly what someone has been trying to find
Sense.TRAN: 不用到别处找了〔表示你所提供的正是某人一直在寻找的〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Want a quiet country retreat for your weekend break? Then look no further!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 周末想在乡村找一个安静的去处吗？那不用到别处找了！

Sense.DEF: if a building looks in a particular direction, it faces that direction
Sense.EXAMPLE: The cabin looks east, so we get the morning sun.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小屋朝东﹐所以我们早上晒得到太阳。

Sense.DEF: used to say that it is sensible to think about possible dangers or difficulties of something before doing it
to be planning or expecting to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re looking to buy a new car early next year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们打算明年年初买一辆新车。 SPOKEN PHRASES 口语短语

Subsense.DEF: used to tell someone to look at something that you think is interesting, surprising etc
Subsense.TRAN: 瞧﹐当心﹐注意﹐留神〔用于让某人注意有趣﹑令人惊讶等的事〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Look! There’s a fox!
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 瞧！有一只狐狸！

Subsense.DEF: used to get someone’s attention so that you can suggest something or tell them something
Subsense.TRAN: 瞧﹐听好〔用于让人注意你要说的事〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Look. Why don’t you think about it and give me your answer tomorrow?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这样吧﹐这事你考虑一下﹐明天给我答复﹐好吗？
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Look, I’ve had enough of this. I’m going home.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 听着﹐我已经受够了﹐我要回家。

Sense.DEF: used to warn someone that they are in danger
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look out! There’s a car coming.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当心！ 有车来了。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone to look at something that you think is interesting, bad etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look at that! What a horrible mess!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看看那个！ 简直是一团糟！

Sense.DEF: used when someone arrives unexpectedly
Sense.EXAMPLE: Well, look who’s here! It’s Jill and Paul!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 哎﹐看谁来了！ 是吉尔和保罗！

Sense.DEF: used to say that you have seen someone but do not want them to know you have noticed them
Sense.TRAN: 现在可别看〔以免让人看到〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Oh no! Don’t look now but here comes Tony.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 哦﹐不好！ 现在别看﹐托尼来了。

Sense.LEXUNIT: look what you’re doing/look where you’re going etc
Sense.DEF: used to tell someone to be careful
Sense.TRAN: 做某事/去某处等要小心
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look where you’re putting your feet! There’s mud all over the carpet!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你落脚要小心！ 地毯上到处都是泥巴！

Sense.DEF: used to angrily tell someone to look at the result of a mistake they have made or something bad they have done
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look what you’ve done – my jacket’s ruined!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看你干了什么呀——我的夹克完蛋了！

Sense.DEF: used to get someone’s attention in order to tell them something, especially when you are annoyed with them
Sense.TRAN: 听着〔用于引起某人的注意以告知其某事﹐尤用于对其感到恼火时〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look here, you can’t say things like that to me!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 听着﹐你不可以跟我那样说话！

Sense.DEF: used when you are in a shop, to say that you are only looking at things, but do not intend to buy anything now
Sense.TRAN: （我）只是看看〔不打算现在就买〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Can I help you?’ ‘No, thanks. I’m just looking.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你要买什么吗？” “不﹐谢谢。 我只是看看。”

Exponent.DEF: to turn your eyes towards someone or something, so that you can see them
Exponent.EXAMPLE: You should never look directly at the sun.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 绝不可直视太阳。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: After a while, he turned and looked at me.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 过了一会儿﹐他转过身来看着我。

Exponent.DEF: to look at something quickly, especially in order to find or check something
Exponent.TRAN: 〔尤指为寻找或检查某物〕看一看
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’ll have a look in my desk.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我会在书桌里找一找。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Take a look at this!
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 看看这个！

Exponent.DEF: to look at someone or something for a short time and then look quickly away
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Damien glanced nervously at his watch.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 达米安紧张地瞥了一眼手表。

Exponent.DEF: to look quickly at something – used especially when you are not supposed to look, or when you are looking through a small gap.
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The door was open so he peeked inside.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 门开着﹐他偷偷朝里面看。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Katy peeped at her birthday present on the table.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 凯蒂悄悄看桌上的生日礼物。

Exponent.DEF: to look very carefully, especially because you cannot see well
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Kenji was peering at the screen.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 健治仔细看着屏幕。

Exponent.DEF: to look at someone in an angry way
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She glared at me as I got up to leave.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我起身要走时她愤怒地瞪着我。

Exponent.DEF: to look at someone or something for a long time without moving your eyes
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It’s rude to stare.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 盯着别人看很不礼貌。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She stared straight into the camera.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她直视相机镜头。

Exponent.DEF: to look at someone or something for a long time, often without realizing that you are doing it
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She gazed out of the window.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她呆呆地望着窗外。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He lay on his bed gazing at the ceiling.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他躺在床上凝视着天花板。

Exponent.DEF: to look at someone or something for a long time, usually with your mouth open, because you are very shocked or surprised
Exponent.EXAMPLE: People gaped at him with wide-open mouths.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们张大嘴巴﹐目不转睛地看着他。

Exponent.DEF: to look at someone or something, especially in a particular way
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He regarded her steadily.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他定定地看着她。

Sense.DEF: to take care of someone by helping them, giving them what they need, or keeping them safe
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t worry, I’ll look after the kids tomorrow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不用担心﹐明天我来照看孩子。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Susan looked after us very well. She’s an excellent cook.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 苏珊把我们照顾得很好﹐她是个很出色的厨师。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You could tell that the horse had been well looked after .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看得出这匹马被照料得很好。

Sense.DEF: to be responsible for dealing with something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m leaving you here to look after the business until I get back.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在我回来之前﹐我让你来料理生意。

Sense.DEF: used when you are saying goodbye to someone in a friendly way
Sense.TRAN: 好好照顾自己﹐保重〔道别语〕

Sense.DEF: to not need anyone else to take care of you
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t worry about Maisie – she can look after herself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不用担心梅茜——她能照顾好自己。

Sense.DEF: to think about and plan for what might happen in the future
Sense.TRAN: 向前看﹐计划未来﹐考虑将来
Sense.EXAMPLE: Looking ahead, we must expect radical changes to be made in our system of government.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 展望未来﹐我们的政治体制必须要有根本性的变革。

Sense.DEF: to try to find something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Jason’s going to start looking around for a new job.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 贾森正打算开始找新工作。

Sense.DEF: to look at what is in a place such as a building, shop, town etc, especially when you are walking
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do we have to pay to look around the castle?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们参观城堡要付费吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s look round the shops.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们去逛逛商店吧。

Sense.DEF: to turn your eyes towards someone or something, so that you can see them
Sense.EXAMPLE: The twins looked at each other and smiled.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这对双胞胎相视而笑。

Sense.DEF: to read something quickly in order to form an opinion of it
Sense.EXAMPLE: I really can’t comment on the report – I haven’t had time to look at it yet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我没法评论这份报告——我还没有时间看一下呢。

Sense.DEF: to examine something and try to find out what is wrong with it
Sense.EXAMPLE: You should get the doctor to look at that cut.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你应该找医生检查一下那处伤口。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can you look at my car? There’s a strange noise coming from the front wheel.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你能检查一下我的汽车吗？ 前轮会发出奇怪的声音。

Sense.DEF: to study and think about something, especially in order to decide what to do
Sense.TRAN: 仔细地考虑﹐研究〔尤指要决定做什么〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We need to look very carefully at ways of improving our efficiency.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要仔细研究提高效率的方法。

Sense.DEF: used to mention someone or something as an example
Sense.TRAN: 看看某人/某事物〔用于举例〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: You don’t have to be smart to be good at music – look at Gary.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学好音乐并非一定要很聪明——你看加里就是了。

Sense.DEF: to think about something in a particular way
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d like to be friends again, but Richard doesn’t look at it that way.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我愿意重归于好﹐可是理查德不这么想。

Sense.DEF: if someone or something is not much to look at, they are not attractive
Sense.TRAN: 〔某人或某物〕并不好看﹐不怎么吸引人

Sense.DEF: to think about something that happened in the past

GramExa.EXAMPLE: When I look back on those days I realize I was desperately unhappy.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 当我回想起那些日子﹐我明白自己当时痛苦极了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Looking back on it, I still can’t figure out what went wrong.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我现在回想起来还是不明白什么地方出了问题。

Sense.DEF: to become more and more successful, especially after a particular success
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指在某一成功之后〕越来越成功
Sense.EXAMPLE: After winning the scholarship he never looked back.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他获得奖学金以后便一帆风顺。

Sense.DEF: to think that you are better than someone else, for example because you are more successful, or of a higher social class than they are
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mr Garcia looks down on anyone who hasn’t had a college education.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 加西亚先生看不起没有受过大学教育的人。

Sense.DEF: to try to find something that you have lost, or someone who is not where they should be
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m looking for Steve – have you seen him?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在找史蒂夫——你见过他吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Detectives are still looking for the escaped prisoner.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警探仍在寻找越狱犯。

Sense.DEF: to be trying to find a particular kind of thing or person
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m sorry, we’re really looking for someone with no family commitments.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对不起﹐我们其实在寻找没有家庭负担的人。

GramExa.PROPFORM: be (just) what/who you are looking for
GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘Salubrious’! That’s just the word I was looking for. salubrious
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: （环境宜人的）!那正是我要找的字眼。

Sense.DEF: to be behaving in a way that makes it likely that problems or violence will happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: They walked into a bar looking for trouble.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们走进酒吧来找碴儿。

Sense.DEF: to be excited and pleased about something that is going to happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m really looking forward to our vacation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我热切期待着我们的假期。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: My mother says she’s looking forward to meeting you.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我母亲说她盼望着与你见面。

Sense.DEF: to make a short visit to someone, while you are going somewhere else, especially if they are ill or need help
Sense.TRAN: 〔顺道〕探望﹐看望〔尤在某人生病或需要帮忙时〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I promised to look in on Dad and see if he’s feeling any better.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我答应去探望爸爸﹐看他是否好一点了。

Sense.DEF: to try to find out the truth about a problem, crime etc in order to solve it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Police are looking into the disappearance of two children.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警察正在调查两个孩子失踪的事。

Sense.DEF: to watch something happening, without being involved in it or trying to stop it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Only one man tried to help us, the rest just looked on in silence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 只有一个人尽力帮助我们﹐其余的人都只是一声不吭地袖手旁观。

Sense.DEF: to consider someone or something in a particular way, or as a particular thing
Sense.TRAN: 〔以某种方式〕对待[看待]某人/某物﹔把某人/某物视为

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I look on him as a good friend.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把他当成好朋友。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Strangers to the village are looked upon with a mixture of fear and suspicion.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们对到村里来的陌生人既害怕又怀疑。

Sense.DEF: to search for and find a particular thing among your possessions
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll look out some of my old books for you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我来从我的旧书中找几本给你。

Sense.DEF: to pay attention to what is happening around you, so that you will notice a particular person or thing if you see them
Sense.TRAN: 注意察看﹐留心〔周围情况﹐以便发现特定的人或物〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look out for your Aunt while you’re at the station.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你到了车站要留神找你姨妈。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s looking out for a nice apartment downtown.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在留意寻找一套位于市中心的舒适公寓。

Sense.DEF: to try to make sure that someone is treated well
Sense.EXAMPLE: My older brother always looked out for me when we were kids.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小时候我哥哥一直照顾我。

GramExa.GLOSS: think only of the advantages you can get for yourself

Sense.DEF: to examine something or someone quickly, without paying much attention to detail
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you have a few minutes to look these samples over?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你能抽几分钟时间看一下这些样品吗？

Sense.DEF:
to
look around
to look for something among a pile of papers, in a drawer, in someone’s pockets etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve looked through all my papers but I still can’t find the contract.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我翻阅了所有文件﹐但依然找不到那份合同。

Sense.DEF: to not notice or pretend to not notice someone you know, even though you see them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I saw Fiona in the street yesterday and she looked straight through me.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 昨天我在街上看到菲奥娜﹐而她假装没有看到我。

Sense.DEF: to depend on someone to provide help, advice etc

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We look to you for support.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们指望得到你的支持。

GramExa.PROPFORM: look to sb to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: They’re looking to the new manager to make the company profitable.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们指望新经理能让公司赢利。

Sense.DEF: to pay attention to something, especially in order to improve it
Sense.EXAMPLE: We must look to our defences.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须注意防守。

Sense.DEF: if a situation is looking up, it is improving
Sense.EXAMPLE: Now the summer’s here things are looking up !
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 夏天到了﹐情况好起来了！

Sense.DEF: if you look up information in a book, on a computer etc, you try to find it there
Sense.EXAMPLE: Look the word up in your dictionary.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 翻翻词典查一下这个词。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll just look up the train times.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我来查一下火车时刻表。

Sense.DEF: to visit someone you know, especially when you are in the place where they live for a different reason
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t forget to look me up when you come to Atlanta.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你来亚特兰大时﹐别忘了来看看我。

Sense.DEF: to admire or respect someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve always looked up to Bill for his courage and determination.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一向佩服比尔的勇气和决心。

Sense.DEF: an act of looking at something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Let me have a look at that – I think it’s mine.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 让我看一下那个东西——我想它是我的。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Take a good look at the photo and see if you recognize anyone in it.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 好好看看这张照片﹐看你能不能认出来里面的哪个人。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I took one look at the coat and decided it wasn’t worth £50.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我看了那件外套一眼﹐觉得不值50英镑。

GramExa.GLOSS: look at all the things in a particular place
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I have a special interest in old houses. Do you mind if I take a look around?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我对老房子特别感兴趣﹐我四处看看行吗？

Sense.DEF: an expression that you make with your eyes or face

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mike gave him such a severe look he didn’t dare argue.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 迈克严厉地看了他一眼﹐他就不敢再争论了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Why has Jake been giving me dirty looks unfriendly looks all morning?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为什么杰克整个上午都不给我好脸色看？

Sense.DEF: an act of examining something and thinking about it

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Have you had a chance to take a look at my proposal yet?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你考虑过我的提议了吗？

Sense.EXAMPLE: I asked the vet to have a quick look at the puppies as well.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我叫兽医顺便也看一下这些小狗。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s time to take a fresh look at the old problem of low pay.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 是时候该重新考虑一下低薪这个老问题了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This month, take a long hard look examine very carefully at where your money is going.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个月﹐好好想一下你的钱怎么用。

Sense.DEF: an attempt to find something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t find them anywhere. Have a look yourself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我哪里也找不着﹐你自己找吧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She had a good look searched carefully through the files.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在文件中仔细地找过了。

Sense.DEF: the appearance that someone or something has
Sense.EXAMPLE: The area has a very seedy look to it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个地区看上去乌烟瘴气。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mr Flynn had a tired, ill look in his eyes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弗林先生的眼中显出倦意和病容。

GramExa.PROPFORM: not like the look of sb/sth
GramExa.GLOSS: think that something bad has happened or will happen because of something’s appearance
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 不喜欢某人/某物的样子〔即认为可能已发生或将要发生不好的事情〕
GramExa.EXAMPLE: We should turn back now. It’s getting dark and I don’t like the look of those rain clouds.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们现在应该回去了。 天越来越黑﹐这乌云密布的样子有些不妙。

Sense.DEF: the way something seems to be
Sense.EXAMPLE: The neighbours are back from holiday by the looks of it that is how it seems .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看样子邻居已经度假回来了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t like the look of this new policy I do not like the way it seems .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不喜欢这项新政策。

Sense.DEF: physical attractiveness
Sense.EXAMPLE: Fiona’s got everything – looks, money and youth.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 菲奥娜什么都有——美貌﹑财富和青春。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You get your good looks from your mother.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你继承了你母亲的美貌。
Sense.EXAMPLE: When she lost her looks became less attractive she found it difficult to get work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有了当年的美貌﹐她觉得找工作难了。

Sense.DEF: a particular style in clothes, hair, furniture etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔服装﹑头发﹑家具等的〕时尚﹐风格﹐样式
Sense.EXAMPLE: The hippy look is back again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 嬉皮士风格又再度流行了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone is looking at someone else in a very angry or unfriendly way
Sense.TRAN: 如果眼神能杀人〔指怒目而视〕

Sense.DEF: someone who looks very similar to someone who is famous
Sense.EXAMPLE: a Madonna lookalike
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个长得酷似麦当娜的人

Sense.DEF: someone who is attractive, usually a woman
to have a chance to take part in or succeed in something
Sense.TRAN: 有参与的机会﹔有成功的希望
Sense.EXAMPLE: Arsenal barely got a look-in were very unsuccessful during the second half of the match.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 下半场中阿森纳队几乎没有任何机会。

Sense.DEF:
a
mirror

Sense.LEXUNIT: be on the lookout for sb/sth
Sense.DEF: to continuously watch a place or pay attention in order to find something you want or to be ready for problems or opportunities
Sense.TRAN: 注意某人/某事﹐留心某人/某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re always on the lookout for new business opportunities.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一直在留意﹐等待新的商机。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Police were on the lookout for anyone behaving suspiciously.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警察在留意形迹可疑的人。

Sense.DEF: to keep watching carefully for something or someone, especially for danger
Sense.TRAN: 密切注视﹐留心〔尤指危险〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We were instructed to keep a lookout for enemy aircraft.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们接到命令要密切注意敌机。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: When you’re driving, keep a sharp lookout watch extra carefully for cyclists.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 开车时要特别注意骑自行车的人。

Sense.DEF: someone whose duty is to watch carefully for something, especially for danger
a place for a lookout to watch from
used to say that someone is responsible for deciding what they will do, and will have to suffer any bad results
Sense.TRAN: 那是某人自己的事﹔这是某人自己的责任
Sense.EXAMPLE: If he wants to keep seeing her, that’s his lookout.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 要是他想继续跟她在一起﹐那是他自己的事。

Sense.DEF: a quick look at something
to appear as a large unclear shape, especially in a threatening way
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指阴森森地〕隐约出现﹐赫然耸现

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Suddenly a mountain loomed up in front of them.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一座大山赫然耸立在他们面前。

Sense.DEF: if a problem or difficulty looms, it is likely to happen very soon
Sense.EXAMPLE: An economic crisis is looming on the horizon .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济危机正在逼近。

Sense.DEF: to seem important, worrying, and difficult to avoid
Sense.EXAMPLE: Fear of failure loomed large in his mind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对失败的担忧沉重地压在他的心头。

Sense.DEF: a frame or machine on which thread is woven into cloth
a large North American bird that eats fish and that makes a long high sound
a silly or strange person – used humorously
someone who is crazy or strange
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her brother’s a complete loony.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的弟弟是个十足的疯子。

Sense.DEF: silly, crazy, or strange
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loony idea
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 古怪的念头

Sense.DEF: an expression meaning a hospital for people who are mentally ill, usually considered offensive
Sense.TRAN: 疯人院﹐精神病院〔一般被认为具有冒犯性〕

Sense.DEF: a shape like a curve or a circle made by a line curving back towards itself, or a piece of wire, string etc that has this shape

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A loop of wire held the gate shut.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一圈铁丝把大门扣上了。

GramExa.GLOSS: a loop of material for holding a belt on trousers etc

Sense.DEF: a set of operations in a computer program that are continuously repeated
a film or music loop contains images or sounds that are continuously repeated
Sense.TRAN: 循环胶片﹔循环磁带〔可循环播放〕

Sense.LEXUNIT: be in the loop/be out of the loop
Sense.DEF: to be or not be part of a group of people who make important decisions
to surprise and upset someone
a road or railway line that leaves the main road or track and then joins it again further on
to make a loop or make something into a loop

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He looped the rope over the post.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他把绳子在柱子上绕了一圈。

Sense.DEF: to move in a circular direction that forms the shape of a loop
Sense.EXAMPLE: The ball looped over the goalkeeper into the back of the net.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个球绕过守门员射入网底。

Sense.DEF:
to fly a plane up and around in a circle so that the plane is
upside down
for a time
a small mistake in a law that makes it possible to avoid doing something that the law is supposed to make you do

GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 法律/税收的漏洞

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a loophole in the law
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 法律上的一个漏洞

Sense.DEF: crazy or strange

Subsense.DEF: to become extremely angry
to become mentally ill

PIC.HEADING: LOOSE 宽松的
PIC.PICCONTENT: tight clothing紧身的衣服；baggy/loose clothing宽松的衣服

Sense.DEF: not firmly fastened in place
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose floorboard
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 松动的地板
Sense.EXAMPLE: This tooth feels very loose.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这颗牙感觉松动得厉害。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The screw has come loose become loose .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 螺丝松了。
Sense.HINTTRAN: Do not confuse the adjective loose /luːs; lus/ with the verb lose /luːz;luz/(=stop having something, become unable to find something etc). 不要将形容词loose与动词lose（失去﹐丢失）混淆: They thought they might lose their jobs. 他们认为自己可能会失业。

Sense.DEF: not attached to anything else
Sense.EXAMPLE: loose papers
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 零散的报纸
Sense.EXAMPLE: His rear wheel spun on the loose stones .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的后轮在散落的石子上打转。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The potatoes are sold loose not packed in a container .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 马铃薯散装出售。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The driver had forgotten to fasten the safety chain and the trailer came loose become unattached .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 驾驶员忘了拴上安全链﹐拖车松脱了。

Sense.DEF: not tied or fastened very tightly
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose knot
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 未系紧的结

Sense.DEF: if your hair is loose, it hangs freely rather than being tied back
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her hair fell loose around her shoulders.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的头发披散在肩上。

Sense.DEF: loose clothes are big and do not fit your body tightly
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose sweatshirt
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宽松的运动衫

Sense.DEF: free from being controlled or held in a cage, prison, or institution
Sense.TRAN: 自由的﹐无束缚的﹐未被关住的

GramExa.GLOSS: escape
GramExa.EXAMPLE: A 34-year-old inmate broke loose from the sheriff’s office yesterday.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 昨天一名34 岁的囚犯从治安官办公室里逃走了。

GramExa.GLOSS: let something go free
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Don’t let your dog loose on the beach.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要让你的狗在沙滩上乱跑。

Sense.DEF: not exact or thoroughly done
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose translation
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不精确的译文
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose interpretation of the law
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对法律不严谨的解释

Sense.DEF: not strictly controlled or organized
Sense.TRAN: 控制不严的﹔组织不严密的﹔松散的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a loose federation of political groups
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 政治团体之间松散的联盟

Sense.EXAMPLE: loose arrangement an arrangement that can easily be changed
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 松散的安排

Sense.DEF: not pressed tightly together in a solid mass

not under the control of either team in a game of football,
rugby
etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sheringham was the first player to reach the loose ball .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 谢林汉姆第一个抢到了这个无人控制的球。

Subsense.DEF: to free yourself from someone or something, or their influence

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He cut himself loose from the constraints of family life.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他摆脱了家庭生活的束缚。

Subsense.DEF: to start enjoying yourself in a happy noisy way after a period of controlled behaviour
Subsense.TRAN: 〔在一段时间的压抑之后〕放任﹐发泄
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’m ready to cut loose and enjoy the weekend.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我准备放任一下自己﹐好好过一个周末。

Sense.DEF: to speak or behave in an uncontrolled way
Sense.TRAN: 痛快地说出（某事物）﹔自由地表现出（某事物）
Sense.EXAMPLE: She let loose a string of four-letter words.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她骂出一连串脏话来。

Sense.DEF: to allow someone to deal with something in the way they want to, when you think they will make mistakes or do something wrong
Sense.EXAMPLE: Whatever you do, don’t let Derek loose on the garden.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们做什么都行﹐就是不能让德里克在花园里乱来。

Sense.DEF: to have nothing to do
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was at a loose end so I decided to go see an old movie.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我闲来无事﹐便决定去看一部老电影。

Sense.DEF: parts of something that have not been completed or correctly done
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve nearly finished, but there are still a few loose ends to be tied up dealt with or completed .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们差不多已经完成﹐还剩些收尾工作。

Sense.DEF: coins that you have in your bag or pocket
someone who cannot be trusted because they say or do things you do not want them to
Sense.TRAN: 炮筒子〔指说话﹑做事随便因而不能相信的人〕

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone to stay calm, or not to worry about something

having a problem in which the waste from your
bowel s
has too much liquid in it
Sense.EXAMPLE: loose bowels
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 腹泻

Sense.DEF: behaving in a way that is considered to be sexually immoral
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose woman
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 荡妇
Sense.EXAMPLE: loose morals
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 放荡的品行

Sense.DEF: not careful about what you say or who is listening
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s been a bit of loose talk about it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对这件事有些不负责任的言论。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: A towel was loosely wrapped around his neck.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的脖子上松松地裹着一块毛巾。
RunOn.EXAMPLE: The film is loosely based on the novel.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 影片大致上根据这部小说改编。

Sense.DEF: to make something unpleasant begin
Sense.TRAN: 释放﹐发泄〔不愉快的事物〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: And now the anger Maggie had feared was loosed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在﹐玛吉所害怕的怒火发泄出来了。

Sense.DEF: to make something loose or to untie someone or something, especially an animal
Sense.TRAN: 释放〔某人或某物﹐尤指动物〕

Sense.DEF:
to fire an
arrow
, a bullet from a gun etc
to allow something dangerous or harmful to begin to affect a situation or other people
Sense.TRAN: 使〔危险或有害的事物〕开始影响[侵袭]〔某种局面或其他人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: the evils loosed upon humanity in World War II
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 第二次世界大战中对人类犯下的种种恶行

Sense.DEF: if a criminal or dangerous animal is on the loose, they have escaped from prison or from their cage
loose-fitting clothes are big and do not fit your body closely, so that they are comfortable
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loose-fitting jacket
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宽松的短上衣

Sense.DEF: having pages that can be put in and removed easily
to make something less tight or less firmly fastened, or to become less tight or less firmly fastened
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’ll need a spanner to loosen that bolt.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你需要扳手来拧开那个螺栓。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The screws have loosened.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 螺丝松了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Harry loosened his tie.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 哈里松开了领带。

Sense.DEF: to make laws, rules etc less strict
Sense.EXAMPLE: Congress has loosened the restrictions on immigration.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 国会已放宽了移民限制。

Subsense.DEF: to reduce the control or power you have over someone or something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The government has loosened its hold on the media considerably.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府已大大放松了对媒体的控制。

Subsense.DEF: to start holding someone or something less tightly than you were before

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He loosened his grip on David’s arm.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他松开了抓着戴维胳膊的手。

Sense.DEF: to make someone talk more than usual, especially about things they should not talk about
Sense.TRAN: 使某人说话不拘束〔尤指说不该说的事〕

Sense.DEF: to stop worrying and become more relaxed, or to make someone do this
Sense.EXAMPLE: She loosened up after she’d had a drink.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一杯酒下肚她便放松了下来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: His welcoming smile helped loosen her up.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那热情的微笑有助于使她放松下来。

Sense.DEF: if your muscles loosen up, or if something loosens them up, they stop feeling stiff

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A massage will loosen up your joints.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 按摩可以放松关节。

Sense.DEF:
to steal things, especially from shops or homes that have been damaged in a war or
riot
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指在战争或暴乱中〕抢劫﹐洗劫﹐掠夺
Sense.EXAMPLE: Shops were looted and burned.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 商店遭到抢劫和焚毁。

Sense.DEF: goods taken by soldiers from a place where they have won a battle
goods or money that have been stolen
things that you have bought or been given in large amounts – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 大量购买[赠送]之物〔幽默用法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jodie came home from the mall with bags of loot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔迪从购物中心满载而归。

Sense.DEF: to cut something, especially branches from a tree, usually with a single strong movement
Sense.TRAN: 〔一般指猛地一下〕砍掉〔尤指树枝〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Workmen have lopped off more branches in an effort to save the tree.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为了救活这棵树﹐工人们砍下了更多的树枝。

Sense.DEF: to reduce an amount, especially of money, by a particular amount
Sense.EXAMPLE: They lopped £16 off the price.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们削价16英镑。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Citicorp plans to lop $1.5 billion a year from its operating costs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 花旗银行计划每年削减15亿美元的运营成本。

Sense.DEF: to run easily with long steps

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He loped off down the corridor.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他沿着走廊大步跑开了。

Sense.DEF: having one side that is lower or heavier than the other
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lopsided grin
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 撇嘴一笑

Sense.DEF: unequal or uneven, especially in an unfair way
Sense.TRAN: 不平等的﹔不平衡的﹔不公正的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lopsided 8-0 victory
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 8比0一边倒的胜利

Sense.DEF: a loquacious person likes to talk a lot

a man who has a rank in the
aristocracy
, especially in Britain, or his title
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lord Salisbury
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 索尔兹伯里勋爵

Sense.DEF:
a man in
medieval
Europe who was very powerful and owned a lot of land
Sense.EXAMPLE: the feudal lords
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 封建领主

Sense.DEF:
used to address a judge or
bishop
, and in the past to address a lord
Sense.TRAN: 大人﹐阁下〔对法官﹑主教的尊称﹐旧时用来称呼贵族〕

Sense.DEF: someone who must be obeyed because they have power over you – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 某人的老板[主人﹐上司]〔幽默用法〕

Sense.DEF: to behave in a way that shows you think you are better or more powerful than someone else
Sense.TRAN: 在某人面前逞威风﹐在某人面前摆架子
Sense.EXAMPLE: He didn’t use his position on the council to lord it over people.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他并没有利用自己在市政会的地位在人前逞威风。

Subsense.DEF: a title of God or Jesus Christ, used when praying
Subsense.TRAN: 主〔祷告时对上帝或耶稣的称呼〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Thank you, Lord, for your blessings.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 感谢主的赐福。

Subsense.DEF: God or Jesus Christ, used when talking about God
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The Lord helps and guides us.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 神帮助并引领我们。

Subsense.DEF: used when you do not know the answer to something
Subsense.TRAN: 天知道〔用于不知道答案时〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Lord knows how old she is now.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 天知道她现在多大年龄了。

Subsense.DEF: used to emphasize that something is true
Subsense.TRAN: 老天知道〔用于强调某事的真实性〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Lord only knows I tried my best to get this right.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老天知道﹐为了搞定这事﹐我是尽了最大努力的。

Sense.DEF: said when you are suddenly surprised, annoyed, or worried about something
Sense.TRAN: 天哪！ 上帝啊！〔表示对某事的惊讶﹑恼怒或忧虑〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Good Lord! Is that the time?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 天哪！ 到时间了吗？

Sense.DEF: the title of someone who has a particular type of official job in Britain
Sense.TRAN: 大人﹐阁下〔英国对某些官员的尊称〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lord Mayor of London
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 伦敦市长大人

Sense.DEF: the House of Lords
a phrase meaning Jesus Christ
behaving in a way that shows you think you are better or more important than other people
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lordly disdain for the common man
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对平民百姓的轻慢

Sense.DEF: very big and impressive
Sense.TRAN: 富丽堂皇的﹔贵族气派的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lordly feast
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 盛大的筵席

Sense.DEF:
the most famous
cricket
ground in the UK, in northwest London. Many important cricket games are played there, and it is the
headquarters
of the MCC, the club which makes the rules for the game of cricket.
Sense.TRAN: 罗德板球场〔英国伦敦西北部著名的板球场﹐玛丽勒本板球俱乐部总部所在地〕

Sense.DEF:
used when talking to or talking about a
lord
, or when talking to a British judge or
bishop
Sense.TRAN: 大人﹐阁下〔对贵族以及英国的法官或主教的尊称〕

Sense.DEF: a man who thinks he is very important – used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 大老爷〔指自命不凡者﹔幽默用法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: So when will his lordship be back?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那么﹐这位大老爷什么时候回来？

Sense.DEF: the most important prayer of the Christian religion
knowledge or information about a subject, for example nature or magic, that is not written down but is passed from person to person
Sense.TRAN: 〔口头流传的关于某一主题的〕知识﹔传说
Sense.EXAMPLE: According to local lore, a ghost still haunts the castle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 根据当地人的传说﹐城堡里至今仍然闹鬼。

Sense.DEF: a large vehicle for carrying heavy goods

Sense.LEXUNIT: it fell off the back of a lorry
Sense.DEF: used humorously to say that something was probably stolen
Sense.TRAN: 多半是偷来之物〔幽默用法〕

Sense.SIGNTRAN: 不再有某种态度/品质等
Sense.DEF: to stop having a particular attitude, quality, ability etc, or to gradually have less of it
Sense.TRAN: 丧失﹐失去〔某种态度﹑品质﹑能力等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve lost my appetite.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我已经没有了胃口。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The business community has lost confidence in the government.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 商界已经对政府失去了信心。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Carol lost interest in ballet in her teens.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 卡萝尔在十多岁的时候对芭蕾舞失去了兴趣。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Try not to lose heart become sad and hopeless - there are plenty of other jobs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要灰心―还有很多其他的工作。

GramExa.GLOSS: stop having as much respect from other people
GramExa.EXAMPLE: A settlement was reached in which neither side lost face.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 达成了一个双方都不失面子的协议。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You’re looking slim. Have you lost weight?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你看上去很苗条啊﹐体重是不是减轻了？
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The plane emptied its fuel tanks as it started losing altitude.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞机开始从高空下降时排空了油箱。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mr Eyer may lose the sight in one eye.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 艾埃尔先生有一只眼睛可能会失明。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The tour was postponed when the lead singer lost his voice.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 由于主唱失声﹐巡回演出推迟了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Julian lost his balance and fell.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 朱利安失去平衡摔倒了。

GramExa.GLOSS: become less skilled at doing something you used to do well
GramExa.EXAMPLE: This latest movie proves Altman is by no means losing his touch.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部最新影片证明奥特曼宝刀未老。

Sense.EXAMPLE: By the time the ambulance arrived, Douglas had lost consciousness .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 救护车赶到时﹐道格拉斯已经失去知觉。

GramExa.PROPFORM: lose all sense of time/direction/proportion etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: When he was writing, he lost all sense of time.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在写作的时候完全没有了时间概念。

GramExa.GLOSS: forget an important fact about a situation
GramExa.EXAMPLE: We must never lose sight of the fact that man must work in harmony with nature.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们绝不能忘记这一点——人类必须与大自然和谐共处。

Sense.DEF: to not win a game, argument, election, war etc
Sense.TRAN: 输掉〔比赛﹑辩论﹑选举﹑战争等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: They played so badly they deserved to lose.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们打得这么差﹐输了活该。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Klinger lost his seat in the election.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 克林格在选举中失去了他的席位。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Arkansas just lost three games in a row.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 阿肯色队一连输了三场比赛。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He just can’t bear to lose an argument.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他和别人争论的时候就是输不起。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The Beavers have dropped only one game since losing to Oregon in January.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 海狸队自1月份败给俄勒冈队以来只输过一场比赛。

GramExa.PROPFORM: lose (sth) by 1 goal/10 votes/20 points etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The government lost by one vote.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府以一票之差落马。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The Communist candidate lost by a whisker a very small amount .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 共产党候选人仅以几票之差落选。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Freddie died in 1982 after losing his battle against AIDS.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弗雷迪与艾滋病抗争失败﹐于1982年去世。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It was a rash decision, and it lost him the race caused him to lose the race .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个决定太轻率﹐使他输掉了比赛。

Sense.DEF: to become unable to find someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve lost the tickets for tonight’s show.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把今晚演出的票弄丢了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I followed her on foot, but lost her in the crowd.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我走在她后面﹐可是在人群中跟丢了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was thought the manuscript had been lost forever .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 原以为这份手稿再也找不着了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The parcel must have got lost in the post.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 包裹肯定是在邮递过程中弄丢了。

GramExa.GLOSS: stop knowing where someone or something is
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 不知道某物/某人的下落
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He lost track of her after her family moved away.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她家搬走以后﹐他就失去了她的音信。

GramExa.GLOSS: stop being able to see someone or something
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Don’t try to walk in a heavy snowstorm as you may lose sight of your vehicle.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 在暴风雪中不要试着下车步行﹐你可能会看不到自己的车子。

Sense.DEF: if you lose something that is important or necessary, you then no longer have it, especially because it has been taken from you or destroyed
Sense.TRAN: 丧失﹐失去〔重要或需要的东西〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: David’s very upset about losing his job .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 戴维失去了工作非常难过。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hundreds of people lost their homes in the floods.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 成百上千的人在水灾中失去了家园。
Sense.EXAMPLE: My family lost everything in the war.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我家在战争中失去了一切。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was over the limit and will lose his licence .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他超速驾驶﹐将被吊销驾驶执照。
Sense.EXAMPLE: 90 naval aircraft were lost and 31 damaged.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 90架海军飞机被毁﹐31架受损。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you hesitate, you may lose the opportunity to compete altogether.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你如果犹豫不定﹐可能连参赛的机会都会失去。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We were losing customers to cheaper rivals.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的客户被出价更低的竞争对手抢去了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: She was about to lose her husband to a younger woman.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的丈夫就要被一个更年轻的女人抢去了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: California has lost 90% of its wetlands to development.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 加州有90%的湿地都被用于开发建设了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He lost his leg in a motorcycle accident.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在摩托车事故中失去了一条腿。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s lost a lot of blood but his life is not in danger.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他失血很多﹐但是没有生命危险。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the mistakes which lost him his kingdom caused him to lose his kingdom
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 使他丢掉了王国的错误

Subsense.DEF: to die
Subsense.EXAMPLE: a memorial to honor those who lost their lives in the war
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 战争死难者纪念碑

Subsense.DEF: if you lose a relative or friend, they die – use this when you want to avoid saying the word ‘die’
Subsense.TRAN: 失去〔亲属﹑朋友﹔die的委婉语〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: One woman in Brooklyn lost a husband and two sons in the gang wars.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在黑帮争斗中﹐布鲁克林的一名妇女失去了丈夫和两个儿子。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Sadly, Anna lost the baby her baby died before it was born .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 安娜不幸流产。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He lost his father to cancer his father died of cancer last year.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年他父亲患癌症去世。

Subsense.EXAMPLE: Peter was lost at sea when his ship sank.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 轮船沉没﹐彼得葬身大海。

Sense.DEF: if you lose money, you then have less money than you had before

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The company is in debt after losing an estimated $30 million on its dotcom enterprise.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司因在网络公司业务上亏损约3,000万美元而负债。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Creditors and investors stand to lose risk losing vast sums after the company’s collapse.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司倒闭之后﹐债权人和投资者可能会蒙受巨大的损失。
Sense.EXAMPLE: A lot of people lost their shirts lost a lot of money on Ferraris in the eighties.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 80年代﹐许多人投资法拉利都赔光了老本。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a great deal – we can’t lose!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这笔生意很合算——我们不会赔钱！

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The stock market crash lost the banks £70 million caused them to lose £70 million .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 股市暴跌使银行损失了7,000万英镑。

Sense.DEF: if you have nothing to lose, it is worth taking a risk because you cannot make your situation any worse
Sense.TRAN: 〔即使不成功也〕不会损失什么﹐不会吃亏
Sense.EXAMPLE: You might as well apply for the job – you’ve got nothing to lose.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不妨申请这份工作——你不会损失什么的。

GramExa.PROPFORM: have nothing to lose but your pride/reputation etc
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The working class has nothing to lose but its chains disadvantages, restrictions etc .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 工人阶级失去的只是锁链。

GramExa.PROPFORM: have a lot/too much to lose
GramExa.GLOSS: used to say that you could make your situation much worse
GramExa.EXAMPLE: These youngsters know they have too much to lose by protesting against the system.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些年轻人知道﹐如果对体制提出抗议﹐他们会损失惨重。

Subsense.DEF: if you lose time, you do not make progress as quickly as you want to or should

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Vital minutes were lost because the ambulance took half an hour to arrive.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 救护车半个小时后才到﹐错过了最关键的几分钟时间。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: In 1978, 29 million days were lost in industrial action.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 1978年因罢工损失了2,900万个工作日。

Subsense.EXAMPLE: Come on, there’s no time to lose do not waste time .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 快点﹐没有时间磨蹭了。

GramExa.PROPFORM: lose no time in doing sth
GramExa.GLOSS: do something immediately
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Murdock lost no time in taking out a patent for his invention.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 默多克一分钟也没有耽误﹐马上为他的发明申请了专利。

Subsense.DEF: if a watch, clock etc loses time, it runs too slowly and shows an earlier time than it should
to stop knowing where you are or which direction you should go in
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I lost my way in the network of tiny alleys.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在纵横交错的小巷子里迷了路。

Subsense.DEF: to become uncertain about your beliefs or what you should do
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The company seems to have lost its way of late.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 近来公司似乎迷失了方向。

Subsense.DEF: if two people lose touch, they gradually stop communicating, for example by no longer phoning or writing to each other
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’ve lost touch with all my old school friends.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我和所有老同学都失去了联系。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: They lost touch when Di got married and moved away.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 迪结婚搬走以后﹐他们就失去了联系。

Subsense.DEF: if you lose touch with a situation or group, you are then no longer involved in it and so do not know about it or understand it
Subsense.TRAN: 〔因不再接触某情况或团体而〕不了解（某事）﹐不明白（某事）
Subsense.EXAMPLE: They claim the prime minister has lost touch with the party.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们声称首相对该党事务已不再了解了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It sometimes appears that the planners have lost touch with reality.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有时候规划者好像与现实脱节。

Sense.DEF: to become angry

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Diana was determined not to lose her temper with him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 黛安娜决意不对他发火。

Sense.DEF: to become unable to behave calmly or sensibly
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’ve all heard that Nadal lost his head over a girl?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们都听说了吗？纳达尔疯狂地爱上了一个女孩。

Sense.DEF: to become crazy
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nicholas looked at her as if she’d lost her mind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尼古拉斯看着她﹐就好像她发疯了一样。

Subsense.DEF: to become very angry and upset
Subsense.EXAMPLE: She completely lost it with one of the kids in class.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她被班上的一个孩子气疯了。

Subsense.DEF: to become crazy or confused
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I could see people thinking I’d totally lost the plot.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我看得出来﹐人们都以为我彻底发疯了。

Sense.DEF: to be paying so much attention to something that you do not notice anything else
Sense.TRAN: 全神贯注于某事﹐专心于某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: She listened intently to the music, losing herself in its beauty.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她专注地听着音乐﹐完全沉浸在美妙的旋律之中。

Sense.DEF: if you lose someone who is chasing you, you manage to escape from them
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s a better chance of losing him if we take the back route.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们如果走小路﹐就更有可能摆脱他。

Sense.DEF: to confuse someone when you are trying to explain something to them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Explain it again – you’ve lost me already.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 再解释一遍吧——你都把我搞糊涂了。

Sense.DEF: to remove a part or feature of something that is not necessary or wanted
Sense.EXAMPLE: You could lose the last paragraph to make it fit on one page.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以把最后一段删掉﹐这样就能放到一页里了。

Sense.DEF: to be less good than the original form
Sense.TRAN: 翻译/转述过程中失去了味道
Sense.EXAMPLE: The joke loses something in the translation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个笑话翻译过来就失去味道了。

Sense.DEF: to not get something good, valuable etc because someone else gets it instead
Sense.TRAN: 失去﹐丧失〔好的或有价值的东西〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The deal will ensure that shareholders do not lose out financially.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个协议将确保股东在经济上不会有损失。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He lost out to Roy Scheider for the lead role.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他当主角的机会被罗伊·施奈德抢走了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Workers who don’t take up training may lose out on promotion.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有接受培训的工人可能会丧失升职机会。

Sense.DEF: someone who is in a worse situation than they were, because of something that has happened
Sense.EXAMPLE: If the strike continues, the people of Galway will be the real losers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果罢工继续下去﹐真正受害的将是戈尔韦地区的人。

Sense.DEF: someone who is never successful in life, work, or relationships
Sense.TRAN: 〔在生活﹑工作或人际关系方面〕屡屡失败的人﹐失败者
Sense.EXAMPLE: What a loser!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 真是个倒霉的人啊！
Sense.EXAMPLE: The guy’s a born loser .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家伙生来就是个失败者。

Sense.DEF: someone who has lost a competition, game, election etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔竞争﹑比赛﹑选举等中的〕失败者﹐输家

GramExa.GLOSS: someone who behaves well or badly after losing

Sense.DEF: the fact of no longer having something, or of having less of it than you used to have, or the process by which this happens

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The court awarded Ms Dixon £7,000 for damages and loss of earnings .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 法院判给狄克逊女士7,000英镑﹐赔偿她所受的损害和收入损失。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a disease which causes fever and a loss of appetite
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 引起发烧和食欲不振的一种疾病
GramExa.EXAMPLE: This did not explain his apparent loss of interest in his wife.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这不能解释他为什么明显对妻子失去了兴趣。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: her loss of confidence in herself
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她对自己信心的丧失
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a certain feeling of loss of control
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一种失去控制的感觉
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a temporary loss of memory
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 暂时的失忆
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The animal was weak through loss of blood .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个动物因为失血而身体虚弱。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The company is closing down two of its factories, leading to 430 job losses .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司要关闭其中的两家工厂﹐这将造成430人失业。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Weight loss should be gradual.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 减肥应该循序渐进。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a type of hearing loss that affects language development
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一种会影响语言能力发展的听力丧失

Sense.DEF: if a business makes a loss, it spends more than it earns
Sense.EXAMPLE: The company made a loss of $250,000 last year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司去年亏损了25万美元。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The magazine’s losses totaled almost $5 million.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家杂志一共损失了将近500万美元。
Sense.EXAMPLE: profit and loss
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 盈亏

GramExa.GLOSS: to earn less money from something you sell than it costs you to produce it
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Two of the mines are running at a loss.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 其中两个矿在亏本经营。

Sense.EXAMPLE: a loss-making rural railway
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 亏损经营的乡村铁路线

Sense.DEF: the death of someone

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She must be feeling very lonely after the loss of her husband.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 丈夫过世以后她一定感到非常寂寞。

Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m sorry to hear of your family’s sad loss the death of someone you love .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 听说你们家痛失亲人﹐我感到非常难过。
Sense.EXAMPLE: US forces withdrew after suffering heavy losses many deaths .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 美军遭受重大伤亡后撤退了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The war has led to a tragic loss of life .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场战争伤亡惨重。

Sense.DEF: to be confused and uncertain about what to do or say
Sense.EXAMPLE: When her son finally left home, Emily felt completely at a loss.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿子终于离开了家﹐埃米莉怅然若失。

GramExa.PROPFORM: be at a loss to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Detectives are so far at a loss to explain the reason for his death.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 到目前为止﹐警探仍非常困惑﹐无法解释他的死亡原因。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He seemed, for once, at a loss for words unable to think what to say .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 就这一次﹐他好像哑口无言了。

Sense.DEF: a feeling of being sad or lonely because someone or something is not there any more
Sense.EXAMPLE: the deep sense of loss I felt after my divorce
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我离婚后产生的深深的失落感

Sense.DEF: a disadvantage caused by someone or something leaving or being removed
Sense.TRAN: 〔因某人的离去或某物的挪移而造成的〕损失

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We see your going as a great loss to the company.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们认为你的离去是公司的重大损失。

Sense.DEF: said when you think someone is being stupid for not taking a good opportunity
Sense.EXAMPLE: Well, if he doesn’t want to come, it’s his loss.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好吧﹐如果他不愿意来﹐那是他自己的损失。

Sense.DEF:
someone who is employed by an insurance company to decide how much should be paid to people who make a
claim
Sense.TRAN: 〔保险公司雇请的〕损失理算师

Sense.DEF: a product that is sold at a very low price in order to attract customers into a shop
a loss-making product or business does not make any money
Sense.EXAMPLE: The company has sold many of its loss-making businesses to cut debts.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司将许多不赢利的业务出售以减轻债务。

Sense.DEF: a way of making a computer file smaller, but which involves losing some of the information in it

the past tense and past participle of
lose
Sense.TRAN: lose 的过去式和过去分词

Sense.DEF: if you are lost, you do not know where you are and are unable to find your way somewhere
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Are you lost?’ the driver asked.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你迷路了吗？”司机问道。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got thoroughly lost on the way here.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我来这里时完全迷了路。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lost child
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个走失的孩子

Sense.DEF: if something is lost, you had it but cannot now find
Sense.EXAMPLE: two boys searching for a lost ball
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在寻找一个丢失的球的两个男孩

Subsense.DEF: lost time or opportunities have not been used in the way that would have given you the greatest advantage
Subsense.TRAN: 〔时间或机会〕用得不恰当的﹔浪费的﹐错过的
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It’ll be impossible to make up the lost time.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 失去的时间不可能追回。

Subsense.DEF: sales, business etc that you could have had but did not
Subsense.TRAN: 损失的销售额/生意/收入等
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The strike has cost the company £2 million in lost revenue.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次罢工给公司收入造成200万英镑的损失。

Sense.DEF: to not feel confident about what to do or how to behave
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s not unusual to feel rather lost when you first start college.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 刚上大学时感到很迷惘不足为奇。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s a great friend and I’d be lost without her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她是一个很不错的朋友﹐没有她我会茫然无措。

Sense.DEF: used to rudely tell someone to go away or to stop annoying you
thinking so hard about something, or being so interested in something, that you do not notice what is happening around you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Harry just stood there, lost in thought .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 哈里就站在那里﹐陷入沉思之中。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Amy lay on her bed, totally lost in her book.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃米躺在床上﹐专心致志地看书。

Sense.DEF: to be forgotten or not noticed in a complicated process or in a busy time
Sense.TRAN: 〔在复杂的过程或忙碌中〕被遗忘[忽略]
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s easy for your main points to get lost in a long speech.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 做长篇演说容易偏离要点。

Sense.DEF: to be completely confused by a complicated explanation
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Do you understand what I mean?’ ‘Not really. I’m a bit lost.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你明白我的意思吗？”“不很明白﹐我有点糊涂了。”

Sense.DEF: if something is lost on someone, they do not understand or want to accept it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The joke was completely lost on Chris.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个笑话克里斯完全没听懂。

Sense.DEF: to be unable to say anything because you are very surprised, upset etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔因非常惊讶﹑难过等〕说不出话来﹐不知说什么才好
Sense.EXAMPLE: For once in her life, she was lost for words.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她平生就这一回不知道说什么话才好。

Sense.DEF: that no longer exists or that you no longer have
Sense.TRAN: 不复存在的﹔不再拥有的
Sense.EXAMPLE: the relics of a lost civilization
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个失落文明的遗迹
Sense.EXAMPLE: She wept for her broken dreams and lost youth.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她为自己破灭的梦想和逝去的青春而哭泣。

Sense.DEF: something that has no chance of succeeding
Sense.EXAMPLE: Trying to interest my son in classical music is a lost cause.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 让我儿子对古典音乐产生兴趣是不可能的事。

Sense.DEF: someone who does not seem to know where they are or what to do – often used humorously
Sense.TRAN: 失魂落魄者﹐茫然若失的人〔常为幽默用法〕

Sense.DEF: used to say that success is still possible, even though there have been problems or failures
Sense.TRAN: 还有一线希望﹔尚未满盘皆输

Crossrefto.REFLEX: give sb up for dead/lost etc
there is no love lost between sb and sb

Sense.DEF: a place where things that are lost are kept until someone comes to claim them
things that people have lost or accidentally left in a public place, which are kept until someone collects them
a place where these things are kept until someone comes to claim them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Thankfully, someone had handed my bag into Lost Property.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 幸好有人把我的包交到了失物招领处。

Sense.DEF: a large amount or number
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve spent a lot on the children’s education.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们在孩子的教育上花费甚多。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘How many CDs have you got?’ ‘Lots.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你有多少张CD？”“多着呢。”

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They paid a lot of money for that house.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们花了很多钱买下那幢房子。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I eat a lot of vegetables.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我吃很多蔬菜。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: There were lots of people at the party.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 聚会上来了很多人。

GramExa.GLOSS: a very large amount or number
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He spends an awful lot of time on the computer.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他将大量时间花在计算机上。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I still have a lot to learn.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我还有很多东西要学。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’s a great city, with lots to see and do.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这座城市很棒﹐有很多可看的东西和可做的事情。

F2NBox.HEADING: GRAMMAR 语法
F2NBox.EXPL: Use a singular verb if you are using a lot of or lots of before an uncountable noun, and a plural verb if you are using it before a plural noun.
F2NBox.TRAN: 如将 a lot of 或 lots of 用在不可数名词前﹐用单数动词 ﹔ 如用在复数名词前﹐则用复数动词
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: A lot of money was spent on it.
A lot of people were killed.
F2NBox.HINTTRAN: Do not say 不要说 ‘lot of’ or 或 ‘a lots of’.
Do not use a lot of with ‘years’ or ‘days’. Say many years/days or a long time. 不要将 a lot of 与 years 或 days连用﹐要说 many years/days 或 a long time 。

F2NBox.HEADING: GRAMMAR 语法
F2NBox.EXPL: A lot is fairly informal and lots is informal. In written English, use many followed by a plural noun, or a large amount followed by an uncountable noun. a lot 较不正式﹐ lots 很不正式 。 在书面英语中﹐复数名词前可用 many ﹐不可数名词前可用 a large amount
F2NBox.BADEXA: This was unpopular for a lot of reasons.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 这不受欢迎有很多原因 。
F2NBox.BADEXA: They spent a lot of money.
F2NBox.GOODEXA: ➔They spent a large amount of money.

Sense.DEF: if someone or something is a lot better, faster, easier etc, they are much better, faster etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: My headache’s lots better, thanks.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的头痛好多了﹐谢谢。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She has a lot more contact with clients these days.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在她和客户联系得更多了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’ll get there a lot quicker if you take the motorway.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果走高速公路去那里会快很多。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The house is a lot tidier now Chris has left home.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 克里斯搬出去之后﹐家里干净多了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something happens to a great degree or often
Sense.EXAMPLE: Things have changed a lot since I was a child.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 从我小时候到现在﹐生活变化很大。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Paul travels a lot on business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保罗经常出差。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve been worrying a lot about my health.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一直非常担心自己的健康。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She likes you a lot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她很喜欢你。

Sense.LEXUNIT: have a lot on your plate
Sense.DEF: to have a large number of problems to deal with or a large amount of work to do
Sense.TRAN: 有很多难题要处理﹔有很多工作要做

Sense.LEXUNIT: have a lot on your mind
Sense.DEF: to have a lot of problems that you are worried about
Sense.TRAN: 有很多操心的事情﹐心事重重
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘You’re quiet today.’ ‘I’ve got a lot on my mind.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你今天话不多。”“我有很多烦心事。”

Sense.DEF: to be very busy, with a large number of things to do in a short time
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t help you now – I’ve got rather a lot on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我现在帮不了你——我很忙。

Crossrefto.REFLEX: have a lot to answer for

Sense.DEF: a group of people or things considered together
Sense.EXAMPLE: Could you help me carry this lot upstairs?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你帮我把这些东西拿到楼上去好吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The last lot of people offered £70,000.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 最后几个人愿意出7万英镑。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I did three lots of exams last summer.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年夏天我参加了三组考试。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Come on, you lot, hurry up!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 来吧﹐你们这帮家伙﹐快点！
Sense.EXAMPLE: His friends are a strange lot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的朋友是一帮怪人。

Sense.DEF: the whole of an amount or number of things, people etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ll do everything – cooking, washing, ironing – the lot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们样样都做——做饭﹑洗衣﹑熨衣服﹐所有的事情。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t believe you ate the whole lot .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我无法相信你全都吃了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think that’s the lot everything is included .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想那就是全部了。

GramExa.GLOSS: all of you, them, or us
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 你们/他们/我们所有的人
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Shut up, the lot of you!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们全都给我闭嘴！

Sense.DEF: your lot is your work, duties, social position etc, especially when they could be better
Sense.EXAMPLE: She seems happy enough with her lot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她好像对自己的境况很满意。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The unions have always tried to improve the lot of their members.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 各工会一直在试图改善其成员的境遇。

Sense.DEF: an area of land used for building on or for another purpose
Sense.TRAN: 一块地﹐场地 〔用于建屋或其他用途〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: the vacant lot empty land behind the Commercial Hotel
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 商务酒店后面的一块空地
Sense.EXAMPLE: a used-car lot
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 旧车场

Sense.DEF: a building and the land surrounding it where films are made
Sense.EXAMPLE: the Universal Studios lot
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 环球影城的片场

Sense.DEF:
something, or a group of things, that is sold at an
auction
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lot 54 is a Victorian lamp.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 54号拍卖品是一盏维多利亚时代的灯。

Subsense.DEF: if someone is chosen by lot, several people each take a piece of paper or an object from a container, and the person who is chosen is the one who gets a particular marked paper or object
Subsense.EXAMPLE: In Athens at that time, judges were chosen by lot .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在那时候的雅典﹐法官是通过抽签来选定的。

Subsense.DEF: to choose something or someone by lot
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We drew lots to decide who should go first.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们抽签决定谁先去。

Sense.LEXUNIT: throw in/cast your lot with sb/sth
Sense.DEF: to join or support someone or something, and accept that what happens to them will affect what happens to you
Sense.EXAMPLE: In 1915 Italy threw in her lot with the Allies.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 1915年﹐意大利把自己的命运与协约国连在了一起。

Sense.DEF:
another spelling of
loath

a man whose main interest is in having sex with as many women as possible without having a serious relationship with any of them. Lothario is a character in Nicholas Rowe’s play The Fair Penitent (1703) who persuades a woman to have sex with him, but is later disloyal to her.
Sense.TRAN: 好色之徒﹐登徒浪子〔源自尼古拉斯·罗尔的剧作《由衷的忏悔》（1703年）中的角色罗沙里奥〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: the office Lothario
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 办公室里的好色之徒

Sense.DEF:
a liquid mixture that you put on your skin or hair to clean,
soften
, or protect it
Sense.TRAN: 〔抹在皮肤或头发上起清洁﹑软化或保护作用的〕洗液﹐洗剂﹔护肤液
Sense.EXAMPLE: suntan lotion
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 防晒露

Sense.DEF: a way of writing ‘lots of’ to show how it sounds when it is spoken
Sense.TRAN: 许多〔lots of的一种写法﹐以说明其发音〕

Sense.DEF:
a game used to make money for a state or a
charity
in which people buy tickets with a series of numbers on them. If their number is picked by chance, they win money or a prize.
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lottery ticket
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 彩票
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you really think winning the lottery would make you happy?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你真的认为彩票中奖会带给你幸福吗？

Sense.DEF: a system of deciding who will get something by choosing people’s names by chance

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The State Department issues 55,000 visas each year by lottery.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 国务院每年随机签发55,000张签证。

Sense.DEF: a situation in which what happens depends on chance and is not certain to be successful
Sense.EXAMPLE: That’s the trouble with capitalism. It’s a lottery.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那是资本主义的问题所在﹐它靠的是运气。

Sense.DEF: a game used to make money, in which people buy tickets with a series of numbers on them. If their number is picked by chance, they win money or a prize.
a white or pink flower that grows on the surface of lakes in Asia and Africa, or the shape of this flower used in decorations
a fruit that gives you a pleasant dreamy feeling after you eat it, according to Ancient Greek stories
Sense.TRAN: 落拓枣﹐忘忧果〔据古希腊传说﹐食后会有一种如梦如幻的快感〕

Sense.DEF:
a way of sitting, used especially in
yoga
, in which you sit with your legs crossed and with each foot resting on the top of the opposite leg
Sense.EXAMPLE: monks sitting in the lotus position
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 打坐的僧人

Sense.DEF: making a lot of noise
Sense.EXAMPLE: The book fell to the floor with a loud bang.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 书砰的一声掉落到地上。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The music was so loud that I had to shout.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 音乐太响了﹐我只得大声地喊。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Who’s there?’ asked David in a loud voice.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “是谁？” 戴维大声问道。

Sense.DEF: someone who is loud talks too loudly and confidently
Sense.TRAN: 〔人〕过于自信而说话声过大的﹐大嗓门的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The more Tom drank, the louder he became.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 汤姆喝得越多﹐嗓门越大。

Sense.DEF: loud clothes are too bright or have too many bright patterns
Sense.EXAMPLE: a loud checked suit
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 扎眼的格子套装

Sense.LEXUNIT: be loud in your praise/opposition/support etc
Sense.DEF: to express your approval or disapproval very strongly
Sense.EXAMPLE: The local business community was loud in its support for the scheme.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当地商界大力支持这个计划。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: She spoke more loudly than she intended.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 她本来无意那么大声说话的。

Exponent.DEF: making a lot of noise – used about sounds, voices, or music
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a loud explosion
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 巨大的爆炸声
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He was talking in a very loud voice.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在大声说话。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The music was too loud.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 音乐太响了。

Exponent.DEF: making a lot of noise – used about people, machines, and places that annoy you
Exponent.TRAN: 〔人〕吵闹的﹐聒噪的﹔〔机器及场所〕嘈杂的﹐喧闹的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The traffic was so noisy.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 车辆噪声真吵。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: noisy neighbours
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 吵闹的邻居
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a noisy bar
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 喧闹的酒吧

Exponent.DEF: rowdy people behave in a noisy and uncontrolled way. A rowdy place such as a bar is full of noisy people, often behaving badly.
Exponent.TRAN: 〔人〕吵闹的﹐粗野的﹔ 〔地方〕喧闹的﹐乱哄哄的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: rowdy football fans
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 吵吵闹闹的足球迷
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a rowdy bar
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 乱哄哄的酒吧

Exponent.DEF: unpleasantly loud – used about the excited sound of groups of people
Exponent.TRAN: 〔激动的人群所发出的声音〕刺耳的﹐吵闹的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: raucous laughter
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 刺耳的笑声
Exponent.EXAMPLE: raucous crowds
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 吵闹的人群

Exponent.DEF: used to describe a loud noise when something hits another thing, that seems to continue for a few seconds. Also used about people cheering or shouting loudly.
Exponent.TRAN: 洪亮的﹔回荡的〔用于形容两物相撞的巨响﹐也用于形容大声欢呼或叫喊的人群〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The door hit the wall with a resounding crash.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 砰的一声巨响﹐门撞到了墙上。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a resounding cheer
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 响亮的欢呼声

Exponent.DEF: extremely loud and deep in sound
Exponent.EXAMPLE: His remarks received thunderous applause from the audience.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的话赢得了观众雷鸣般的掌声。

Exponent.DEF: so loud that you cannot hear anything else
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The noise was deafening – like a thousand fireworks going off at one time.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 那声音震耳欲聋﹐仿佛上千烟花同时炸响。

Exponent.DEF: so loud that your ears feel uncomfortable
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He played the music at ear-splitting volume.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他把音乐放得震耳欲聋。

Exponent.DEF: extremely loud, high, and unpleasant to hear
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a piercing scream
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 一声尖叫

Sense.DEF: in a way that makes a lot of noise
Sense.EXAMPLE: Could you speak a little louder?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你能不能说得大声点？
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’ve got the telly on too loud.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你把电视机开得太响了。

Sense.DEF: in a way that is very easy to understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: The message came through loud and clear.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那消息传达得清清楚楚。

Sense.DEF: in such a way that people can hear you
Sense.EXAMPLE: Read it out loud, so we can all hear.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大声念出来﹐这样我们都能听到。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Harriet laughed out loud in astonishment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 哈丽雅特吃惊得大声笑了出来。

Sense.DEF:
a piece of equipment with a
microphone
, that you can hold in your hand and speak through to make your voice louder
someone who talks too much and says offensive or stupid things
Sense.TRAN: 多嘴饶舌的人﹔说话不中听的人

Sense.DEF: a piece of equipment used to make sounds louder

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The voice over the loudspeaker using the loudspeaker said the flight was delayed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 喇叭里传来声音说航班误点了。

Sense.DEF:
a
speaker 3
in Ireland, a lake or a part of the sea almost surrounded by land
Sense.TRAN: 〔爱尔兰的〕湖﹔〔几乎为陆地所环绕的〕海湾
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lough Neagh
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 内伊湖

Sense.DEF:
a
waiting room
at an airport
Sense.EXAMPLE: the departure lounge
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 候机室

Sense.DEF: a public room in a hotel or other building, that is used by many people as a place to relax
Sense.EXAMPLE: the television lounge
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 电视放映室

Sense.DEF: the main room in a house where people relax, watch television etc
a lounge bar

a
cocktail bar
to stand, sit, or lie in a lazy or relaxed way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nathan was lounging on the grass bank outside the cottage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 内森正懒洋洋地躺在小屋外的草堤上。

Sense.DEF: to spend time relaxing and doing nothing, often when you should be doing something
Sense.TRAN: 百无聊赖地消磨[打发]时间
Sense.EXAMPLE: James does nothing but lounge around the apartment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 詹姆斯在公寓里转来转去﹐无所事事。

Sense.DEF:
a comfortable bar in a
pub
or hotel
Sense.TRAN: 〔小酒馆或宾馆中的〕雅座酒吧

Sense.DEF:
a
sun lounger
a suit that a man wears during the day, especially to work in an office
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指在办公室上班时穿的〕西装（套服）

Sense.DEF: a small insect that lives on the hair or skin of people or animals
someone who is nasty and unpleasant
to make something worse rather than better, or to spoil something
Sense.EXAMPLE: That idiot loused up my chance of promotion.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个白痴破坏了我升迁的机会。

Sense.DEF: of very bad quality
Sense.EXAMPLE: What lousy weather!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 多么糟糕的天气！
Sense.EXAMPLE: The food was lousy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 食物糟透了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: a lousy film
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一部烂片

Sense.DEF: if you feel lousy, you feel ill
not very good at doing something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m lousy at tennis.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我网球打得很差。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Brenda’s lousy with kids.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 布伦达对付孩子不行。

Sense.EXAMPLE: a lousy teacher
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个差劲的老师

Sense.DEF: small, useless, or unimportant
Sense.TRAN: 不起眼的﹔不起作用的﹔微不足道的
Sense.EXAMPLE: He left me a lousy fifty cent tip.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他给了我区区50美分的小费。

Subsense.DEF: a place that is lousy with people of a particular kind is too full of them
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The town was lousy with tourists.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 镇上挤满了游客。

Subsense.DEF: someone who is lousy with money has a lot more of it than they need

Sense.DEF: a rude, violent man
a narrow piece of wood, glass etc in a door or window, that slopes towards the outside to let some light in and keep rain or strong sun out
a door or window made of these pieces of wood, glass etc
friendly and attractive
Sense.TRAN: 友善可爱的﹐讨人喜欢的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a sweet lovable child
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 十分讨人喜欢的孩子

Sense.DEF:
to have a strong feeling of
affection
for someone, combined with sexual attraction
Sense.EXAMPLE: I love you, Tracy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我爱你﹐特雷西。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was the only man she had ever loved.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是她唯一爱过的男人。

Sense.DEF: to care very much about someone, especially a member of your family or a close friend
Sense.TRAN: 爱﹐关爱〔尤指家人或好友〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I love my grandad so much.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我非常爱我的爷爷。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve always loved children.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一向喜欢孩子。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: In 1941, her much-loved sister was killed in an accident.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 1941年﹐她深爱的妹妹死于一场事故。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Many people feel guilty after the death of a loved one .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多人在至爱之人死后有一种负疚感。

Sense.DEF: to like something very much or enjoy doing something very much
Sense.TRAN: 喜欢﹐喜爱〔某物或做某事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I love carrots.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我喜欢吃胡萝卜。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jeff loves his work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 杰夫热爱他的工作。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I love the way she sings that song.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我喜欢她唱那首歌的方式。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Amy had always loved New York.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃米一向喜欢纽约。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I love going out to restaurants.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我喜欢去餐馆吃饭。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We all love to talk about ourselves.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们都喜欢谈论自己。

GramExa.GLOSS: used to say that you would really like to do something
GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘Would you like to come swimming with us?’ ‘I’d love to.’
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: “你想和我们一起去游泳吗？” “我很愿意。”
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’d have loved to have stayed till the end.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我是很想一直留到结束的。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’d love to know just why they did that.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我就是很想知道他们为什么那么做。

Sense.DEF: to have a strong feeling of loyalty to your country, an institution etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dad’s always loved the navy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 爸爸一直热爱海军。

Sense.DEF: used when you are amused by something, especially by someone else’s mistake or bad luck
Sense.TRAN: 好玩！ 太有趣了！〔尤用于表示觉得别人的差错或坏运气好笑〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘And then her boyfriend walked in and saw her kissing Ray.’ ‘I love it!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “就在那时﹐她男朋友进来了﹐看到她正在亲吻雷。” “这太有意思了！”

Subsense.DEF: used to say that someone will enjoy something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Listen guys, you’re going to love this.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大家听好了﹐你们一定会喜欢这个。

Subsense.DEF: used to say that someone will not be pleased about something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’m going to love telling him we’ve changed our minds again.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我可不想告诉他我们又改主意了。

Exponent.DEF: to like someone very much and care a lot about them – used about people in your family or someone who you are sexually attracted to
Exponent.TRAN: 爱﹐关爱〔用于家人或爱人〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I love my wife and children very much.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很爱我的妻子和孩子。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Have you ever said ‘I love you’ and not really meant it?
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 你有没有过嘴上说 “我爱你” 而心里却不这么想的时候？

Exponent.DEF: to love and admire someone very much
Exponent.EXAMPLE: When she was a child she adored her father.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她小时候非常爱她父亲。

Exponent.DEF: to feel that you love someone and want to have a romantic relationship with them
Exponent.EXAMPLE: We were both young and very much in love.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们都很年轻﹐深深相爱。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Karen was in love with a man who was much older than her.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 卡伦爱上了一个比她年长许多的男人。

Exponent.DEF: to love someone a lot and keep thinking about them, in a way that seems silly because you do not know them very well
Exponent.TRAN: 对某人痴迷〔指不甚了解的人〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He became infatuated with a woman he met at a conference.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他迷上了一个开会时遇到的女人。

Exponent.DEF: to love and be sexually attracted to someone you are not having a relationship with, usually someone older
Exponent.TRAN: 迷恋某人〔通常指比自己年长的人〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Jane had a crush on the German teacher.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 简迷恋上了那位德语老师。

Exponent.DEF: to love someone very much – used for emphasis
Exponent.TRAN: 疯狂地爱上某人〔用于强调〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She’s crazy about you.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她迷上你啦。

Exponent.DEF: to love someone very much and give them a lot of attention
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He was devoted to his wife and his children.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他深深爱着妻子和孩子。

Exponent.DEF: to love someone very much, especially a much younger family member, and behave very kindly to them
Exponent.TRAN: 宠爱[溺爱]某人〔尤指年纪比自己小得多的家庭成员〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He dotes on his grandchildren.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他很宠孙辈。

Sense.DEF: a strong feeling of caring about someone, especially a member of your family or a close friend
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指对家人﹑好友的〕爱﹐关心﹐关爱
Sense.EXAMPLE: What these kids need is love and support.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些孩子需要的是关心和支持。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a mother’s love for her child
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 母亲对孩子的爱

Sense.DEF: a strong feeling of liking someone a lot combined with sexual attraction

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Their love for each other grew deeper every day.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们之间的爱与日俱增。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Tara is madly in love with you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 塔拉疯狂地爱着你。

Sense.DEF: someone that you feel a strong romantic and sexual attraction to
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was her first love .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是她的初恋情人。

GramExa.GLOSS: the person that you feel or felt the most love for

Subsense.DEF: a strong feeling of pleasure and enjoyment that something gives you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: my love of nature
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我对大自然的热爱
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He had a great love of music.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他非常热爱音乐。

Subsense.EXAMPLE: I fell in love with Amsterdam the very first time I visited the city.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我第一次到阿姆斯特丹就喜欢上了这座城市。

Subsense.DEF: something that gives you a lot of pleasure and enjoyment
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Sailing was her great love.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 帆船运动是她最大的爱好。

Subsense.DEF: to have sex with someone that you love

to say
loving
things to someone, to kiss them etc

Sense.LEXUNIT: send/give your love (to sb),send/give sb your love
Sense.DEF:
to ask someone to give your
loving
greetings to someone else when they see them, write to them etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Aunt Mary sends her love.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛丽姑妈向你问好。

Sense.LEXUNIT: love (from sb)/lots of love/all my love
Sense.DEF: used at the end of a letter to a friend, a member of your family, or someone you love
Sense.TRAN: 爱你的/深爱你的/全心爱你的〔用于写给朋友﹑家人或所爱之人的信的末尾处〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: See you soon. Lots of love, Clare.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 希望很快能见到你。 深爱你的﹐克莱尔。

Subsense.DEF: a word used when you are talking to someone you love
Subsense.TRAN: 亲爱的〔用于对所爱的人说话时〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘Hello, love,’ said her father.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你好啊﹐亲爱的。” 她父亲说。

Subsense.DEF: a friendly way of talking to someone who you do not know, especially to a woman or child. Many women consider this to be impolite or offensive.
Subsense.TRAN: 亲爱的〔对陌生人说话的友好方式﹐尤用于妇女或儿童﹔许多女性认为这种说法不礼貌或具有冒犯性〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: What’s your name, love?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你叫什么名字﹐亲爱的？

Sense.LEXUNIT: be a love and .../... there’s a love
Sense.DEF: used when you are asking someone, especially children and members of your family, to do something
Sense.TRAN: 做个乖宝宝…/…好乖乖〔尤用于要孩子和家人做某事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Give these to your sisters, there’s a love.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 把这些拿去给你的姐姐们﹐好乖乖。

Sense.LEXUNIT: there is no love lost between sb and sb
Sense.DEF: if there is no love lost between two people, they dislike each other
Sense.TRAN: 某人和某人之间没有好感﹐某人与某人互相厌恶

Sense.DEF: an expression meaning ‘no points’, used in the game of tennis
if you cannot get something or do something for love or money, it is impossible to obtain or to do
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t get hold of that book for love nor money.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我无论如何也找不到那本书。

Sense.DEF: a situation in which someone is having a sexual relationship with the partner of a close friend – used especially in newspapers
Sense.TRAN: 三角恋爱〔尤用于报纸文章〕

Sense.DEF: used to show that you are extremely angry, disappointed etc
Sense.TRAN: 看在上帝的份上〔用于表示怒不可遏﹑极度沮丧等〕

ColloBox.HEADING: COLLOCATIONS 词语搭配 – MEANING 义项 2

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Are you in love with her?
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 你是不是爱上她了？

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: start being in love
Collocate.EXAMPLE: I fell in love with her the minute I saw her.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我对她一见钟情。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: meet someone to love
Collocate.EXAMPLE: I never thought I would find love.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我永远找不到爱情。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: love someone who loves you
when you love someone as soon as you meet them
Collocate.EXAMPLE: For Marion and Ron it was love at first sight.
